Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Observations and Analysis of Wave-Induced Constituent Transport in the Mesopause Region above Cerro Pachon, Chile and Table Mountain, Colorado
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a 5-year scientific collaboration to investigate vertical transport mechanisms in the upper mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) using a combination of theory, observations, and atmospheric chemical models. The study focuses on the mesopause region, 80-105 km altitude, and employs Na and Fe wind/temperature lidar, meteor radar, and airglow data from two observation sites at Cerro Pachon, Chile, and Table Mountain, CO. The objectives are to quantify wave-induced vertical transport in the mesopause region above these sites, to characterize its effects on the fluxes and vertical distribution of heat, Na, Fe, O, and other key constituents, and to compare the measurements to the eddy diffusion parameterization schemes that are traditionally used to account for vertical transport in atmospheric chemistry models. Specific scientific goals include:
1) To characterize the vertical fluxes of heat, Na (at Cerro Pachon) and Fe (at Table Mountain) throughout the mesopause region and throughout the year,
2) To determine the effective vertical constituent transport velocities associated with advection, turbulent mixing, dynamical transport and Na/Fe chemistry and to characterize their seasonal variations,
3) To quantify the influence of wave-induced transport on the structure and seasonal variations of the mesospheric Na and Fe layers by comparing model predictions with observations,
4) To characterize the effective vertical transport associated with OH Meinel Band, O(1S) green line and O2 Atmospheric Band airglow emissions throughout the year at Cerro Pachon, and
5) Through model calculations to assess the influence of wave-induced transport on the structure and variations of other important mesospheric constituents such as atomic O.

Intellectual Merit: Knowledge of the magnitude and variability of wave-induced vertical transport is important to a wide range of research problems, including general circulation modeling, atmospheric chemistry modeling, thermal balance calculations, and the study of the mesospheric airglow and metal layers. This work will contribute to a much deeper understanding of the key gravity wave transport processes and their relationships to atmospheric chemistry. In addition, this work will significantly enhance our ability to model the constituent structure of the MLT, particularly the meteoric metal and airglow layers.

Broader Impacts: The research has broader implications for atmospheric science because the results can be used to characterize the impact of wave-induced transport on other important constituents in other atmospheric regions, such as stratospheric ozone, which in turn affects the thermal balance of the Earth's atmosphere. Hence, the results of this project may have important applications in global climate modeling. Furthermore, the direct measurements of the vertical fluxes of mesospheric Fe and Na, in combination with modeling, will substantially improve current estimates of the absolute value of the global meteoric input flux, which are highly uncertain. This is important because the meteoric debris that enters the MLT is eventually transported into the lower atmosphere, where it affects the formation of stratospheric aerosols and is ultimately deposited in the oceans, where it contributes to the concentration of key chemical species, such as Fe. Both stratospheric aerosols and oceanic Fe play important roles in Earth's climate. Stratospheric aerosols reflect sunlight, which alters the Earth's radiation budget, while oceanic Fe promotes the growth of phytoplankton, which affects the global carbon cycles, in particular atmospheric CO2.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth’s upper atmosphere is essential for sustaining life by absorbing extreme solar radiation, ablating meteoric material, regulating gaseous escape, dissipating energetic particles and fields from space, while balancing influences from the planet itself in the form of tsunami-like atmospheric waves propagating upward from below. This project addressed the effects of these waves, specifically their impact on the chemical composition and thermal structure of the upper atmosphere. As the atmospheric waves propagate upward, the wind velocities associated with them increase as the atmospheric density decreases. Eventually the waves become unstable and break, generating turbulence, which transports both heat and gases downward. These transport effects were studied theoretically and experimentally  by measuring the downward fluxes of heat, atomic Na and atomic Fe by using Doppler lidar (light-detection-and-ranging) measurements.

Na and Fe atoms are deposited in the Earth’s atmosphere between about 50 and 70 miles altitude, by the vaporization of high-speed cosmic dust particles. The ablated atoms and meteoric smoke particles (MSPs) are transported downward by waves and pole ward by the prevailing winds and eventually settle onto the Earth’s surface. This cosmic debris is involved in a wide variety of atmospheric chemical processes, plays important roles in the formation of mesospheric and stratospheric clouds and, when the iron-rich MSPs settle into the Southern Ocean around Antarctica, they fertilize the growth of phytoplankton, which impacts the atmospheric CO2 cycle and potentially climate.

Several of the project accomplishments are particularly interesting and noteworthy. The simultaneous Na and Fe flux observations have shown conclusively that the majority of the ablated cosmic dust particles entering the Earth's upper atmosphere are traveling in prograde orbits around the sun and originate from the Jupiter Family of Comets. By deriving the theoretical relationship between the meteoric influx, chemical loss and vertical transport induced by waves and turbulence and applying the theory to lidar observations of the Na flux profile, we obtained significantly improved estimates for the global Na vapor influx and global dust influx. The global Na vapor influx is 389±18 kg/d. The total cosmic dust mass influx is 107±22 t/d, assuming the dust composition is identical to ordinary chondrites (7680 ppm by mass). These results have important implications for a wide variety of atmospheric processes including the formation of the mesospheric metal layers. The development of the theoretical description for the chemical fluxes will enable this process to be included in atmospheric models, which should substantially improve the model predictions for chemically active species such as odd-O, HOX, NOX and in particular for the mesospheric metal layers. The development of the lidar techniques for measuring the eddy constituent, heat and momentum fluxes and the demonstration of the first direct eddy heat flux measurements has opened a new and important window for studying the impact of waves and turbulence on the Earth’s upper atmosphere.

The Na and Fe vertical flux measurements have improved our understanding of the major sources of cosmic dust entering the atmosphere and of the particle velocity distribution. The new more accurate estimate of the total cosmic dust mass influx to the Earth's atmosphere improves understanding of how meteoric ablation affects the formation of polar mesospheric clouds and polar stratospheric clouds, ozone chemistry over the polar caps and the fertilization of phytoplankton in the Southern Ocean by meteoric Fe.
